subject: Data
title: The Census of Ancient Rome
description: A 60-second lesson on The Census of Ancient Rome.

hook.text: Every five years, Rome demanded that every citizen declare their wealth, family, and property.

buildup.text: The census wasn't curiosity â€” it determined your tax rate and military obligation.

discovery.text: Rome used census data to plan roads, allocate grain, and project army sizes across the empire.

twist.text: Lying on the census was punishable by enslavement. Rome took its data very seriously.

climax.text: The Roman census was the most sophisticated data collection until the modern nation-state.

punchline.text: Empires run on data. Rome proved it first.
